awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Computational Models, Topological Games, and Classical Information
awd_abstract_narration:
Modern computer systems are too complex to be analyzed directly, and often mathematical models are employed to analyze such computer systems to understand how well they function and whether they operate correctly. The area of computational models is devoted to constructing such models, and to their application to solve problems in computing, such as specifying computational devices designed to solve specific problems. Quite distinct from this, the area of Diophantine approximation from number theory studies how well real numbers can be approximated by rational numbers - ones that can be expressed a quotient of two integers. Despite dating back to the time of Diophantus of Alexandria, there are many deep questions here that remain unsolved. Finally, the study of classical communication channels forms the basis for the area of classical information theory that plays a fundamental role in many aspects of everyday life. This project will explore relationships between emerging techniques for building computational models, and research in classical information and in Diophantine approximation. These represent very diverse areas of mathematics, computer science and information theory, and a goal of the project is to develop links between them that reveal common underlying principles that can be applied to solve problems in each area. Such principles will lead to methods that can be used from one area to solve problems in the other areas. 

The proposed work spans a number of research areas: domain theory and computational models; topological games; classical information and families of classical channels; analysis of complex systems; and applications to Schmidt games and Diophantine approximation. Recent results on channel capacity that underpin the work are based on a topological view of channels and their capacity that offers a unique way to analyze related families of channels. The proposed analysis of existing approaches to constructing domain models of spaces - the co-algebraic approach as opposed to one based on Choquet games - will explore the relationship between these approaches, and will provide insights into their applicability to new and interesting problems in the range of areas listed above. Using domain-theoretic approaches to analyze Schmidt games is a novel idea that should prove useful in understanding these games and how they differ from ones such as Choquet games.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on applying tools from the mathematical area of domain theory to understanding the principles and models for Schmidt games. These games were first devised by W. Schmidt as a way to understand what are called "badly approximable (real) numbers". The aim is to understand which real numbers can be easily approximated using Diophantine approximation methods, as opposed to those that it is intrinsically hard to approximate. The reasons this is interesting are, from a mathematical perspective, it is important to understand the nature of real numbers, and from a computer science perspective, it is important to know which approximation problems can be easily solved - and hence would require only a small amount of computational power - and which ones require more resources. Diophantine approximation is one of the fundamental tools for approximating real numbers, e.g. on a computer, a problem that has applications in all of the many areas where computing real values is important.

The specific results of this project have impact both for the mathematical aspect described above, and for the computational aspect. The results themselves concern how to realize Lebesgue measure on the unit interval, [0,1] - this is what is used to define the standard integral we use in Calculus. In devising his original results, Schmidt proved what is now regarded as an almost folklore result: Lebesgue measure can be obtained as a quotient of Haar measure on an infinite product of two-point groups, i.e., on (Z2)∞. An abstract chaaracetrization of this group is as a Cantor group, meaning one that is defined on a Cantor set. Our work greatly extends this result by showing that any Cantor group G, which means a topological group on the Cantor set, admits a quotient map to the interval that takes Haar measure on G to Lebesgue measure on [0,1]. Moreover our results show that all Haar measures on a Cantor set are "essentially the same", meaning that there is a Borel isomoprhism between the Borel sets of any two of them taking one Haar measure to the other. 

We further show how each of the quotient mappings described above can be realized as a limit of mappings from finite groups - for which Haar measure is normalized counting measure - onto the space of subintervals of the unit interval. This leads to a "built-in" method for approximating Lebesgue measure on the interval by simple measures in a variety of ways. This has potential applications in approximating integrals over the interval in a computationally simple way. 

The work on this project has also been useful in a related project of the PI that concerns how to devise computational models for probabilistic computation. The aim in this area is to define mathematical models that can be used to reason about computations that rely on probabilistic phenomena - for example, the randomized algorithms of Rabin that have been proved to be better than any previously known solutions. The line of work that the PI and one of his graduate students have pursued is to define random variable computational models. The results from this NSF project have proved useful because the random variable models we have found to be most useful are ones supported on models based on the Cantor set, in particular, on various Cantor groups that one can define. 

Finally, work on this project also has led to new applications of a combination of information theory and domain theory to the analysis of anonymity protocols used in security. The new analysis is aimed at understanding vulnerabilities of existing anonymity protocols to attacks where the adversary only observes traffic, rather than corrupting nodes on the network.
